column2: The Scottish Terrier as a show dog dates from about 1877 to 1879.
column3: The Scottish Terrier as a show dog dates from about eighteen seventy seven to eighteen seventy nine.

column2: He seems almost at once to have attained popularity, and he has progressed gradually since then, ever in an upward direction, until he is to-day one of the most popular and extensively owned varieties of the dog.
column3: He seems almost at once to have attained popularity, and he has progressed gradually since then, ever in an upward direction, until he is to day one of the most popular and extensively owned varieties of the dog.

column2: Sir Paynton Pigott had, at the date mentioned, a very fine kennel of the breed, for in _The Live Stock Journal_ of May 30th, 1879, we find his kennel fully reviewed in a most enthusiastic manner by a correspondent who visited it in consequence of a controversy that was going on at the time, as to whether or not there was such a dog at all, and who, therefore, wished to see and judge for himself as to this point.
column3: Sir Paynton Pigott had, at the date mentioned, a very fine kennel of the breed, for in underscore The Live Stock Journal underscore of may thirtieth eighteen seventy nine, we find his kennel fully reviewed in a most enthusiastic manner by a correspondent who visited it in consequence of a controversy that was going on at the time, as to whether or not there was such a dog at all, and who, therefore, wished to see and judge for himself as to this point.

column2: At the end of his report on the kennel the writer adds these words: "It was certainly one of the happiest days of my life to have the pleasure of looking over so many grand little dogs, but to find them in England quite staggered me.
column3: At the end of his report on the kennel the writer adds these words: "It was certainly one of the happiest days of my life to have the pleasure of looking over so many grand little dogs, but to find them in England quite staggered me.

column2: Four dogs and eight bitches are not a bad beginning, and with care and judicious selection in mating, I have little doubt but Mr. Pigott's kennel will be as renowned for Terriers as the late Mr. Laverack's was for Setters.
column3: Four dogs and eight bitches are not a bad beginning, and with care and judicious selection in mating, I have little doubt but mr Pigott's kennel will be as renowned for Terriers as the late mr Laverack's was for Setters.

column2: I know but few that take such a delight in the brave little 'die-hards' as Mr. Pigott, and he may well feel proud of the lot he has got together at great trouble and expense."

column2: The fact that there was such a kennel already in existence proved, of course, a strong point in favour of the _bona fides_ of the breed.
column3: The fact that there was such a kennel already in existence proved, of course, a strong point in favour of the underscore bona fides underscore of the breed.

column2: The best dog in it was Granite, whose portrait and description were given in the _Journal_ in connection with the said review; and the other animals of the kennel being of the same type, it was at once recognised that there was, in fact, such a breed, and the mouths of the doubters were stopped.
column3: The best dog in it was Granite, whose portrait and description were given in the underscore Journal underscore in connection with the said review; and the other animals of the kennel being of the same type, it was at once recognised that there was, in fact, such a breed, and the mouths of the doubters were stopped.

column2: Granite was unquestionably a typical Scottish Terrier, even as we know them at the present day.
column3: Granite was unquestionably a typical Scottish Terrier, even as we know them at the present day.

column2: He was certainly longer in the back than we care for nowadays, and his head also was shorter, and his jaw more snipy than is now seen, but his portrait clearly shows he was a genuine Scottish Terrier, and there is no doubt that he, with his kennel mates, Tartan, Crofter, Syringa, Cavack, and Posey, conferred benefit upon the breed.
column3: He was certainly longer in the back than we care for nowadays, and his head also was shorter, and his jaw more snipy than is now seen, but his portrait clearly shows he was a genuine Scottish Terrier, and there is no doubt that he, with his kennel mates, Tartan, Crofter, Syringa, Cavack, and Posey, conferred benefit upon the breed.

column2: To dive deeper into the antiquity of the Scottish Terrier is a thing which means that he who tries it must be prepared to meet all sorts of abuse, ridicule, and criticism.
column3: To dive deeper into the antiquity of the Scottish Terrier is a thing which means that he who tries it must be prepared to meet all sorts of abuse, ridicule, and criticism.

column2: One man will tell you there never was any such thing as the present-day Scottish Terrier, that the mere fact of his having prick ears shows he is a mongrel; another, that he is merely an offshoot of the Skye or the Dandie; another, that the only Scottish Terrier that is a Scottish Terrier is a white one; another, that he is merely a manufactured article from Aberdeen, and so on _ad infinitum_.
column3: One man will tell you there never was any such thing as the present day Scottish Terrier, that the mere fact of his having prick ears shows he is a mongrel; another, that he is merely an offshoot of the Skye or the Dandie; another, that the only Scottish Terrier that is a Scottish Terrier is a white one; another, that he is merely a manufactured article from Aberdeen, and so on underscore ad infinitum underscore.

column2: It is a most extraordinary fact that Scotland should have unto herself so many different varieties of the terrier.
column3: It is a most extraordinary fact that Scotland should have unto herself so many different varieties of the terrier.

column2: There is strong presumption that they one and all came originally from one variety, and it is quite possible, nay probable, that different crosses into other varieties have produced the assortment of to-day.
column3: There is strong presumption that they one and all came originally from one variety, and it is quite possible, nay probable, that different crosses into other varieties have produced the assortment of to day.

column2: The writer is strongly of opinion that there still exist in Scotland at the present time specimens of the breed which propagated the lot, which was what is called even now the Highland Terrier, a little long-backed, short-legged, snipy-faced, prick or drop-eared, mostly sandy and black-coloured terrier, game as a pebble, lively as a cricket, and all in all a most charming little companion; and further, that to produce our present-day Scottish Terrier--or shall we say, to improve the points of his progenitor?--the assistance of our old friend the Black and Tan wire-haired terrier of England was sought by a few astute people living probably not very far from Aberdeen.
column3: The writer is strongly of opinion that there still exist in Scotland at the present time specimens of the breed which propagated the lot, which was what is called even now the Highland Terrier, a little long backed, short legged, snipy faced, prick or drop eared, mostly sandy and black coloured terrier, game as a pebble, lively as a cricket, and all in all a most charming little companion; and further, that to produce our present day Scottish Terrier-or shall we say, to improve the points of his progenitor?--the assistance of our old friend the Black and Tan wire haired terrier of England was sought by a few astute people living probably not very far from Aberdeen.

column2: Scottish Terriers frequently go by the name of Aberdeen Terriers--an appellation, it is true, usually heard only from the lips of people who do not know much about them.
column3: Scottish Terriers frequently go by the name of Aberdeen Terriers-an appellation, it is true, usually heard only from the lips of people who do not know much about them.

column2: Mr. W. L. McCandlish, one of the greatest living authorities on the breed, in an able treatise published some time back, tells us, in reference to this matter, that the terrier under notice went at different periods under the names of Highland, Cairn, Aberdeen, and Scotch; that he is now known by the proud title of Scottish Terrier; and that "the only surviving trace of the differing nomenclature is the title Aberdeen, which many people still regard as a different breed--a want of knowledge frequently turned to account by the unscrupulous dealer who is able to sell under the name of Aberdeen a dog too bad to dispose of as a Scottish Terrier." But there can be no doubt that originally there must have been _some_ reason for the name.
column3: mr w l McCandlish, one of the greatest living authorities on the breed, in an able treatise published some time back, tells us, in reference to this matter, that the terrier under notice went at different periods under the names of Highland, Cairn, Aberdeen, and Scotch; that he is now known by the proud title of Scottish Terrier; and that "the only surviving trace of the differing nomenclature is the title Aberdeen, which many people still regard as a different breed-a want of knowledge frequently turned to account by the unscrupulous dealer who is able to sell under the name of Aberdeen a dog too bad to dispose of as a Scottish Terrier." But there can be no doubt that originally there must have been underscore some underscore reason for the name.

column2: In a letter to the writer, Sir Paynton Pigott says, "Some people call them and advertise them as the Aberdeen Terrier, which is altogether a mistake; but the reason of it is that forty years ago a Dr. Van Bust, who lived in Aberdeen, bred these terriers to a large extent and sold them, and those buying them called them, in consequence, 'Aberdeen Terriers,' whereas they were in reality merely a picked sort of Old Scotch or Highland Terrier." Sir Paynton himself, as appears from the columns of _The Live Stock Journal_ (March 2nd, 1877), bought some of the strain of Van Bust, and therein gives a full description of the same.
column3: In a letter to the writer, Sir Paynton Pigott says, "Some people call them and advertise them as the Aberdeen Terrier, which is altogether a mistake; but the reason of it is that forty years ago a dr Van Bust, who lived in Aberdeen, bred these terriers to a large extent and sold them, and those buying them called them, in consequence, 'Aberdeen Terriers,' whereas they were in reality merely a picked sort of Old Scotch or Highland Terrier." Sir Paynton himself, as appears from the columns of underscore The Live Stock Journal underscore (march second eighteen seventy seven), bought some of the strain of Van Bust, and therein gives a full description of the same.

column2: Sir Paynton Pigott's kennel of the breed assumed quite large proportions, and was most successful, several times winning all the prizes offered in the variety at different shows.
column3: Sir Paynton Pigott's kennel of the breed assumed quite large proportions, and was most successful, several times winning all the prizes offered in the variety at different shows.

column2: He may well be called the Father of the breed in England, for when he gave up exhibiting, a great deal of his best blood got into the kennels of Mr. H. J. column3: He may well be called the Father of the breed in England, for when he gave up exhibiting, a great deal of his best blood got into the kennels of mr h j Ludlow, who, as everyone knows, has done such a tremendous amount of good in popularising the breed and has also himself produced such a galaxy of specimens of the very best class.

column2: Mr. Ludlow's first terrier was a bitch called Splinter II.
column3: mr Ludlow's first terrier was a bitch called Splinter two.

column2: The name of Kildee is, in the breed, almost world-famous, and it is interesting to note that in every line does he go back to the said Splinter II.
column3: The name of Kildee is, in the breed, almost world famous, and it is interesting to note that in every line does he go back to the said Splinter two.

column2: Rambler--called by the great authorities the first pillar of the stud book--was a son of a dog called Bon-Accord, and it is to this latter dog and Roger Rough, and also the aforesaid Tartan and Splinter II. that nearly all of the best present-day pedigrees go back.
column3: Rambler-called by the great authorities the first pillar of the stud book-was a son of a dog called Bon Accord, and it is to this latter dog and Roger Rough, and also the aforesaid Tartan and Splinter two. that nearly all of the best present day pedigrees go back.

column3: This being so, it is unnecessary to give many more names of dogs who have in their generations of some years back assisted in bringing the breed to its present state of perfection.

column2: An exception, however, must be made in the case of two sons of Rambler, by name Dundee and Alister, names very familiar in the Scottish Terrier pedigrees of the present day.
column3: An exception, however, must be made in the case of two sons of Rambler, by name Dundee and Alister, names very familiar in the Scottish Terrier pedigrees of the present day.

column2: Alister especially was quite an extraordinary stud dog.
column3: Alister especially was quite an extraordinary stud dog.

column2: His progeny were legion, and some very good terriers of to-day own him as progenitor in nearly every line.
column3: His progeny were legion, and some very good terriers of to day own him as progenitor in nearly every line.

column2: The best descendants of Alister were Kildee, Tiree, Whinstone, Prince Alexander, and Heather Prince.
column3: The best descendants of Alister were Kildee, Tiree, Whinstone, Prince Alexander, and Heather Prince.

column2: STANDARD OF POINTS OF THE SCOTTISH TERRIER: SKULL--Proportionately long, slightly domed and covered with short hard hair about 3/4 inch long or less.
column3: STANDARD OF POINTS OF THE SCOTTISH TERRIER: SKULL-Proportionately long, slightly domed and covered with short hard hair about three quarters inch long or less.

column2: It should not be quite flat, as there should be a sort of stop or drop between the eyes.
column3: It should not be quite flat, as there should be a sort of stop or drop between the eyes.

column2: MUZZLE--Very powerful, and gradually tapering towards the nose, which should always be black and of a good size.
column3: MUZZLE-Very powerful, and gradually tapering towards the nose, which should always be black and of a good size.

column2: The jaws should be perfectly level, and the teeth square, though the nose projects somewhat over the mouth which gives the impression of the upper jaw being longer than the under one.
column3: The jaws should be perfectly level, and the teeth square, though the nose projects somewhat over the mouth which gives the impression of the upper jaw being longer than the under one.

column2: EYES--A dark-brown or hazel colour; small, piercing, very bright and rather sunken. EARS--Very small, prick or half prick (the former is preferable), but never drop.
column3: EYES-A dark brown or hazel colour; small, piercing, very bright and rather sunken. EARS-Very small, prick or half prick (the former is preferable), but never drop.

column2: They should also be sharp pointed, and the hair on them should not be long, but velvety, and they should not be cut.
column3: They should also be sharp pointed, and the hair on them should not be long, but velvety, and they should not be cut.

column2: The ears should be free from any fringe at the top.
column3: The ears should be free from any fringe at the top.

column2: NECK--Short, thick and muscular; strongly set on sloping shoulders.
column3: NECK-Short, thick and muscular; strongly set on sloping shoulders.

column2: CHEST--Broad in comparison to the size of the dog, and proportionately deep.
column3: CHEST-Broad in comparison to the size of the dog, and proportionately deep.

column2: BODY--Of moderate length, but not so long as a Skye's, and rather flat-sided; well ribbed up, and exceedingly strong in hind-quarters.
column3: BODY-Of moderate length, but not so long as a Skye's, and rather flat sided; well ribbed up, and exceedingly strong in hind quarters.

column2: LEGS AND FEET--Both fore and hind legs should be short and very heavy in bone, the former being straight and well set on under the body, as the Scottish Terrier should not be out at elbows.
column3: LEGS AND FEET-Both fore and hind legs should be short and very heavy in bone, the former being straight and well set on under the body, as the Scottish Terrier should not be out at elbows.

column2: The hocks should be bent, and the thighs very muscular, and the feet strong, small and thickly covered with short hair, the fore feet being larger than the hind ones.
column3: The hocks should be bent, and the thighs very muscular, and the feet strong, small and thickly covered with short hair, the fore feet being larger than the hind ones.

column2: TAIL--Should be about 7 inches long, never docked, carried with a slight bend and often gaily.
column3: TAIL-Should be about seven inches long, never docked, carried with a slight bend and often gaily.

column2: COAT--Should be rather short (about 2 inches), intensely hard and wiry in texture, and very dense all over the body.
column3: COAT-Should be rather short (about two inches), intensely hard and wiry in texture, and very dense all over the body.

column2: SIZE--From 15 lb. to 20 lb.; the best weight being as near as possible 18 lb. for dogs, and 16 lb. for bitches when in condition for work.
column3: SIZE-From fifteen l b to twenty l b; the best weight being as near as possible eighteen l b for dogs, and sixteen l b for bitches when in condition for work.

column2: COLOUR--Steel or iron grey, black brindle, brown brindle, grey brindle, black, sandy and wheaten.
column3: COLOUR-Steel or iron grey, black brindle, brown brindle, grey brindle, black, sandy and wheaten.

column2: White markings are objectionable, and can only be allowed on the chest and to a small extent.
column3: White markings are objectionable, and can only be allowed on the chest and to a small extent.

column2: GENERAL APPEARANCE--The face should wear a very sharp, bright and active expression, and the head should be carried up.
column3: GENERAL APPEARANCE-The face should wear a very sharp, bright and active expression, and the head should be carried up.

column2: The dog (owing to the shortness of his coat) should appear to be higher on the leg than he really is; but at the same time he should look compact and possessed of great muscle in his hind-quarters.
column3: The dog (owing to the shortness of his coat) should appear to be higher on the leg than he really is; but at the same time he should look compact and possessed of great muscle in his hind quarters.

column2: In fact, a Scottish Terrier, though essentially a terrier, cannot be too powerfully put together, and should be from about 9 inches to 12 inches in height.
column3: In fact, a Scottish Terrier, though essentially a terrier, cannot be too powerfully put together, and should be from about nine inches to twelve inches in height.

column2: SPECIAL FAULTS: MUZZLE--Either under or over hung.
column3: SPECIAL FAULTS: MUZZLE-Either under or over hung.

column2: EYES--Large or light-coloured.
column3: EYES-Large or light coloured.

column2: EARS--Large, round at the points or drop.
column3: EARS-Large, round at the points or drop.

column2: It is also a fault if they are too heavily covered with hair.
column3: It is also a fault if they are too heavily covered with hair.

column2: LEGS--Bent, or slightly bent, and out at elbows.
column3: LEGS-Bent, or slightly bent, and out at elbows.

column2: COAT--Any silkiness, wave or tendency to curl is a serious blemish, as is also an open coat. SIZE--Specimens of over 20 lb. should be discouraged.
column3: COAT-Any silkiness, wave or tendency to curl is a serious blemish, as is also an open coat. SIZE-Specimens of over twenty l b should be discouraged.

column2: There have, of recent years, been many very excellent specimens of the Scottish Terrier bred and exhibited.
column3: There have, of recent years, been many very excellent specimens of the Scottish Terrier bred and exhibited.

column2: It is highly probable that of all the terrier tribe, the "Scottie," taken as a whole, is the best companion.
column3: It is highly probable that of all the terrier tribe, the "Scottie," taken as a whole, is the best companion.

column2: He makes a most excellent house-dog, is not too big, does not leave white hairs about all over the place, loves only his master and his master's household, and is, withal, a capable and reliable guard.
column3: He makes a most excellent house dog, is not too big, does not leave white hairs about all over the place, loves only his master and his master's household, and is, withal, a capable and reliable guard.

column2: He is, as a rule, a game, attractive terrier, with heaps of brain power, and from a show point of view there is always some recompense in keeping him, as it will be found he breeds true to type and does not beget offspring of all sorts, shapes, and makes.
